You have reached the end of the eCRF. Please ensure you have completed the following actions: 1) Complete the patient follow-up card with the follow-up date 28 days from now: 2) Ensure you have given the patient their follow-up appointment card. 3) Ensure the adult sample collection eCRF is completed. 4) Ensure the adult treatment eCRF is completed once the information is available

Please remember to enter the lab results in the lab form, as soon as the results are available.

Thank you

Welcome to the electronic FIEBRE patient data collection form: Clinical history & physical exam for adults 15 years.
Please make sure that all the appropriate materials and supplies are ready.

This includes: hard copies of the patient information sheet and consent form, study ID stickers, and blood collection tubes.

These questions relate to the patient's primary residence
For example, any of the following drilled well, dug well, bottle, lake, river
Check pulse using automated means (eg. Pulse oximeter or BP or vital signs monitor), if checking manually check for 60 seconds against the clock. If missing or unobtainable enter 999.

Press on the patient's sternum firmly for 5 seconds, then count the number of seconds it takes to return to normal colour. This sign is often difficult to see for patients with dark skin. If the skin on the sternum does not change colour with pressure, try the nose. If you are not confident you can see the skin change colour after pressing on it, enter 999.
Enter 999 if unable to measure
Enter 999 if unable to measure
Enter 999 if unable to measure
Enter 999 if unable to measure
No shoes, no coat or jacket, enter to 1 decimal place, if missing or not obtainable enter 999 and explain why on next page.
Without shoes, standing upright, looking straight ahead, enter to the nearest cm, if missing or unobtainable enter 999, if unobtainable explain why.

select.hint: If patient does not respond to voice, exert firm pressure on the patient's nail bed and assess response

select1.hint: Any movement of any part of the body counts as movement
Can be smallish pus filled lesion (boil), or a very large pus filled lesion (abscess)
For example, small crusted black lesion for example, left after a tick or insect bite common in borreliosis and anthrax and some other illnesses
This is a fluid filled vesicle (not puss filled) eg chickenpox rash
A puss filled cavity eg. Herpes simplex or folliculitis
Purpura or petechiae caused by meningococcal sepsis
